title: Cochlear Dead Regions (CDR)
chief_complaint: I don't receive the benefit I hoped for from my hearing aids; there is a lack of clarity in noise and sounds are tinny and harsh at high levels.

problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Distortion ('tinny and harsh'), difficulty in noise
problem_summary.functional_impact: Perceives less benefit than the people she helps in her volunteer work.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Highly motivated to achieve better performance; has scheduled 9 appointments in the last 2 years for reprogramming.

history.present_illness: Patient has worn bilateral digital hearing aids for 5 years. Reports lack of clarity in noise and harsh/tinny sound quality at high input levels. She feels her aids are not programmed correctly.
history.otologic_history: Long-standing bilateral asymmetrical sensorineural hearing loss.
history.prior_management: Consistent hearing aid use. Frequent reprogramming appointments (9 in 2 years).
history.patient_goals: Improve clarity and reduce harshness; match the benefit she sees others receiving.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral asymmetric SNHL. Right ear is poorer than left at 1000-2000 Hz. Right ear shows moderate loss sloping to profound. Left ear shows moderate-to-severe loss sloping to profound.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Very poor ability to recognize speech bilaterally, with right ear significantly poorer than left.

numeric_results.WRS_Right: 33% at 80 dB HL, 60% at 110 dB HL
numeric_results.WRS_Left: 80% at 80 dB HL, 80% at 110 dB HL

tests.name: Threshold Equalizing Noise (TEN) test
tests.key_findings: Positive for Cochlear Dead Regions (CDRs). 'Off-frequency listening' detected.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Elevated or absent reflexes consistent with SNHL.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: Aided speech tests performed to assess word recognition ability after diagnosis.

numeric_results.Sentence_Recognition: 73% at 65 dBA (monitored live voice, no visual cues)

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, sloping from moderate to profound in the high frequencies. Speech recognition is disproportionately poor in the right ear (max 60%). The TEN test confirmed the presence of Cochlear Dead Regions (CDRs) at 1000 and 3000 Hz in the right ear and 3000 Hz in the left ear, explaining the distortion and lack of benefit from high-frequency amplification.
counseling_points: Explain 'Cochlear Dead Regions': Areas of the inner ear where hair cells are non-functioning.
Clarify that amplifying sound in these 'dead' regions causes distortion ('tinny/harsh' sounds) rather than clarity.
Recommend reducing amplification in the high frequencies (above 1700 Hz in the right ear) to improve comfort and reduce noise.
Discuss the importance of communication strategies, optimal positioning, and speechreading to supplement hearing.
Suggest assistive devices like remote wireless microphones for meetings.
notes_for_actor: You are knowledgeable about hearing aids because you volunteer with the elderly, which makes your own lack of benefit more frustrating.
You have been persistent, returning 9 times in 2 years, convinced the aids just need 'reprogramming'.
You describe sounds as 'tinny' and 'harsh' when they are loud.
You are initially skeptical that *less* volume (reducing high frequencies) will help, as you feel you already can't hear enough.
